task_summary: The robot must pick up the canned spam and place it into the sink as observed in the sequence of frames.

task_long_description.overview: A single-arm robot is tasked with perceiving, grasping, and transferring a canned spam object into the sink in a controlled kitchen environment. The sequence involves object detection, precise grasping using a side approach, and transferring the item over to the sink area. Visual verification ensures accurate placement, and a release followed by a retreat completes the action. The scene consists of a compact kitchen mockup with the spam can and sink clearly visible and accessible.
preconditions: Spam can is present and within the robot's reachable workspace.
The sink is empty and accessible.
Robot gripper is initially open and ready.
stepwise_plan: Check if the spam can is visible; scan if not.
Detect precise location of the spam can.
Open the gripper and move above the can.
Compute and approach a side grasp pose.
Perform the grasp and verify stability.
Check for visibility of the sink.
Place the can on the sink surface.
success_criteria: Spam can is securely placed inside the sink.
No objects are dropped during transport.
failure_and_recovery: Spam can not detected: rescan up to 3 times.
Grasp not stable: abort or retry approach.
task_long_description.termination: BT terminates after robot releases the spam can in the sink and retreats.

frame_3.now_evidence: first stable contact and alignment cue visible
frame_3.predicts_next: push actuation expected; confirms goal direction

task_instruction: Put the canned spam into the sink

node_specs.description: Checks if spam can is visible to sensors.
Performs focused scan for spam can.
Moves end effector above spam can.
Computes a side grasp pose for the can.
Checks if the grasp is secure.
Places canned spam on sink surface with light force.
Opens gripper to release can in sink.

failure_modes: Spam can or sink not detected
Failed grasp or dropped object during approach or transfer
recovery_strategy: Rescan up to 3 times for spam can or sink
Repeat approach sequence if grasp unstable
Retry gripper operation on open failure
assumptions: Assumed the can in the image is 'spam_can' per task instruction.
Sink location deduced from visual evidence of workspace.
Side grasp pose selected due to visible can access.
Instruction and frames are aligned; no major conflicts.

expected_success_criteria: Can stably in sink, gripper open, arm retracted
